Graphical abstract Benzoic acid production from toluene has been achieved by a novel electrocatalytic oxidation method. The designed Mn x Ce1− x O2/CNT displays outstanding toluene oxidation performance owing to optimal C–H activation. Electrocatalytic toluene (TL) oxidation to produce benzoic acid (BAC) process is largely hindered due to sluggish kinetics associated with the transformation of the rate-determining step, because of weak TL adsorption and high rate-determining step energy barrier for difficult to dehydrogenate. Herein, we report Mn x Ce1- x O2/CNT catalyst for accelerated reaction kinetics. Theoretical and experimental studies indicate that Ce sites promote TL adsorption and polyvalent Mn modulates the electronic structure of Ce sites reducing the rate-determining step energy barrier. This results in increasing *C6H5CH2 coverage and effectively accelerating TL oxidation reaction (TOR) kinetics. Excitingly, the Faraday efficiency (FE) and BAC yield of optimized Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT at 2.6 V vs. RHE could reach 85.9% and 653.9 mg h−1 cm−2, respectively. In addition, the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT displays a high selectivity of 96.3% for BAC. Combining the TL oxidation reaction with hydrogen evolution reaction, the anion exchange membrane electrolyzer of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT (+) ||Pt/C (−) can reach 100 mA cm−2 at the voltage of 3.0 V, in which the BAC yield is 579.4 mg h−1 cm−2 and the FE is 83.6%. This work achieved high selectivity of TOR at industrial-relevant current densities of 100 mA cm−2 at the low voltage for the first time. Keywords Electrocatalytic oxidation AEM electrolyzer Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst Toluene oxidation Benzoic acid 1 Introduction Benzoic acid (BAC) is a significant organic product in the petrochemical industry, which can be used as raw material for chemical intermediates, sodium benzoate preservatives, and crude oil recovery diverters [1–6]. Conventionally, the industrial production of BAC from toluene (TL) mainly involves liquid-phase oxidation of toluene with oxygen [7–9]. However, the thermocatalytic methods typically necessitate harsh conditions (high temperature or high O2 pressure) [10] and strong oxidants (such as hydrogen peroxide and tert-butyl) [11] to generate reactive oxygen species, all of which can negatively impact the environment. Therefore, conventional industrial production of BAC not only leads to higher energy consumption and production costs but also causes environmental pollution. In conclusion, developing a new green-energy process with high BAC selectivity, low energy consumption, and high safety is imminent and challenging. As an alternative, renewable energy-poared electrocatalysis is a sustainable strategy for oxidizing organic compounds to value-added oxygenates under mild conditions that have considerable promise for development [12–17]. In this regard, a large amount of surface active oxygen (*OH) [18–20] generated by water electrolysis is directly utilized as a sustainable oxygen source for electrocatalytic oxidation to avoid the use of hazardous O2. However, this process is largely hindered due to sluggish kinetics associated with the transformation of the rate-determining step *C6H5CH3 dehydrogenation to produce *C6H5CH2, because of weak TL adsorption and high C(sp 3)–H bond dissociation energy (dissociation energy: 440 kJ mol−1) [21,22] for difficult to dehydrogenate. The reactions on the anodic side are usually accompanied by the competitive oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [23–27] due to the favorable water dissociation, eventually leading to poor Faraday efficiency (FE) and conversions. Additionally, the lack of effective control on the specific adsorption of BAC at high production conversions greatly limits the yields of targeted products due to over-oxidation reactions [28,29]. Here, by screening a range of metal oxides, we found that CeO2 has the best activation effect on C–H bonds. Meanwhile, CeO2 activation of C–H bonds has also been reported in some related reports. Li’s group employed a Pt/CZ (CZ is Ce-Zr solid solutions) catalyst for photocatalytic cyclohexane C–H bond activation[30]. Ganduglia-Pirovano and Senanayake et al. reported Pd-iC-CeO2 catalysts for methane C–H bond activation [31]. Wang’s group assembled a Pd1/CeO2 catalyst for methane C–H bond activation [32]. Mn ion not only has different valence states playing different roles, but also displays strong Mn–O bonds with good stability [33–38]. Therefore, we chose Mn to incorporate it into CeO2 for proposing a Mn x Ce1− x O2/CNT catalyst to improve the electrocatalytic performance of TL oxidation reaction (TOR). Density functional theory (DFT) calculation and experimental results jointly display that Ce sites could improve the TL adsorption on the catalyst surface and reduce the energy barrier for the dehydrogenation of *C6H5CH3, so that the C–H bond on the methyl group of TL is easily activated and the *C6H5CHc3 is facilely dehydrogenated to form *C6H5CH2; meanwhile Mn modulates the electronic structure of Ce, reducing the rate-determining step energy barrier and promoting the BAC desorption to avoid over-oxidation. This results in increasing *C6H5CH2 coverage and effectively accelerating TOR kinetics. In addition, we found that Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT has the best TOR performance. If the content of Mn is low, the effect of Mn on CeO2 electron transfer is weak; on the contrary, when the content of Mn is too high, it will lead to the number of active sites becoming less, so the highest TOR activity is found when the Mn/Ce is 6/4, which is consistent with the experimental results. Therefore, the obtained Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT exhibits fast kinetics to promote the conversion of TL to BCA. At the current density of 100 mA cm−2, the FE of BAC reaches 85.9%, the selectivity is 96.3%, and the yield is 653.9 mg h−1 cm−2. In addition, combining TOR with hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), the anion exchange membrane (AEM) electrolyzer of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT (+) || Pt/C (−) can reach 100 mA cm−2 at the voltage of 3.0 V, in which the BAC yield is 579.4 mg h−1 cm−2 and the FE is 83.6%. This work achieved high-selectivity TOR at industrial-relevant current densities of 100 mA cm−2 at the low voltage for the first time [39,40]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials A carboxylated carbon nanotube (CNT) is bought from Aladdin. The materials needed included Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (98%, Macklin), Ce(NO3)2·6H2O (99.5%, Aladdin), toluene (99.5%, Yantai Far East Fine Chemical Co., Ltd), BAC (99.5%, Aladdin), CH3OH (99.5%, Aladdin), CH3CH2OH (99.5%, Aladdin), phosphoric acid (85 wt% in H2O, Aladdin), KOH (90%, Macklin), HCl (37%, Aladdin), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) (99.9%, Aladdin), CDCl3, Nafion solution (5%, Sigma-Aldrich). All deionized water (18 MΩ cm) used in the experiments is prepared using an ultra-pure purification system (Aqua Solutions). 2.2 Materials synthesis 2.2.1 Preparation of MnO2/CNT catalysts Firstly, 100.0 mg of processed CNT and 100.0 mg of Mn(NO3)2·4H2O are mixed and ground in a mortar for 30 min to mix evenly. Then, the mixture is put into a 10 mL quartz bottle and the bottle is filled with Ar, which is then put in a household microwave (Midea, PM2001) for 60 s at a power of 700 W. Then, the resultant products are washed with water and ethanol and centrifuged. Finally, the product is dried overnight in a 60 °C oven to obtain powder. 2.2.2 Preparation of CeO2/CNT catalysts Firstly, 100 mg of processed CNT and 100.0 mg of Ce(NO3)2·6H2O are mixed and ground in a mortar for 30 min to mix evenly. Then, the mixture is put into a 10 mL quartz bottle and the bottle is filled with Ar. The subsequent steps are same as that for preparing MnO2/CNT catalysts. 2.2.3 Preparation of MnxCe1−xO2/CNT catalysts To prepare Mn0.8Ce0.2O2/CNT, 139.6 mg Mn(NO3)2·4H2O, 60.4 mg Ce(NO3)2·6H2O, and 100.0 mg CNT are mixed in a mortar for 30 min. The subsequent steps are same as that for preparing MnO2/CNT catalysts. Keeping the amount of CNT constant, other comparative catalysts can be obtained by varying the addition of Mn(NO3)2·4H2O and Ce(NO3)2·6H2O. Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT was obtained by 92.9 mg Mn(NO3)2·4H2O and 107.1 mg Ce(NO3)2·6H2O. Mn0.5Ce0.5O2/CNT was obtained by 73.3 mg Mn(NO3)2·4H2O and 126.7 mg Ce(NO3)2·6H2O. Mn0.4Ce0.6O2/CNT was obtained by 55.7 mg Mn(NO3)2·4H2O and 144.4 mg Ce(NO3)2·6H2O. Mn0.2Ce0.8O2/CNT was obtained by 25.3 mg Mn(NO3)2·4H2O and 175.7 mg Ce(NO3)2·6H2O. 2.3 Materials characterizations To study the morphology and structure of the catalyst, Hitachi S-4800 scanning electron microscopy (SEM) is tested. The morphology of the sample is characterized using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) at an accelerated voltage of 200 kV on JEM-2100 UHR. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, scanning at a rate of 1° min−1 at the range of 2θ from 2° to 90° with Cu K α radiation, is performed on the X'Pert PRO MPD diffractometer (PANalytical, Netherlands) at 40 kV and 40 mA to examine the composition of the synthesized samples. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is performed using the VG ESCALABMK II spectrometer. All electrochemical properties of the sample are measured on an electrochemical workstation (CHI 760E). Element content is determined by an inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES, Varian 710-ES). Quantitative analysis of H2 generated by the electrolysis process is performed using gas chromatography (GC 7900) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), flame ionization detector (FID), and Ar (99.999%) as carrier gas. 1H Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectra are recorded in a designated solvent on the Bruker AVANCE NEO 400 MHz liquid NMR spectrometer. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements The electrocatalyst (4.0 mg) is dispersed in 1.0 mL ethanol and Nafion mixed solution. The obtained ink is dropped onto the carbon cloth with the size of 1 × 1 cm2 to get the corresponding electrode. To avoid contamination, electrodes are used either immediately after preparation or kept in a vacuum before being used in electrochemical experiments. On the CHI 760 electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Zhenhua Instrument Corporation, Shanghai, China), electrochemical measurements are conducted in a conventional three-electrode bath, with a platinum plate as the counter electrode and a saturated calomel electrode as the reference electrode. All electrochemical measurements are converted to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). All potentials measured in TL + 1.0 M KOH or 1.0 M KOH solution are converted to approximately RHE values according to the following Eq. (1). (1) E R H E = E S C E + 0.244 V + 0.0592 × p H TL and 1.0 M KOH solution are directly used as oxidizing and reducing substrates, respectively. In addition, adding 0.1 g sodium dodecyl sulfate as a surfactant increases the solubility of TL. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) is performed at a scanning rate of 5 mV s−1. Electrochemical double-layer capacitance (C dl) measurements are carried out using cyclic voltammetry (CV). In TL + 1.0 M KOH, the potential was selected beyond the possible Faraday area of the material to record the CV at different scan rates of 20–100 mV s−1. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is performed on the PAR-STAT 2273 testing system, with a frequency range of 100 kHz to 1 Hz at an alternating current (AC) signal amplitude of 0.8 V vs. RHE. Dual electrode electrolysis is performed on an H-cell electrochemical workstation with an anion exchange membrane. For the dual-electrode electrolysis cell of TOR and HER, Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT is used for the anode and Pt/C is used for the cathode, including 1.0 M KOH and 1 mol L−1 TL solution for the anode as well as 1.0 M KOH solution for the cathode. Then, timing current tests are performed at different potentials. To analyze the products in the anode and cathode chambers, Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT is used in a two-electrode configuration to measure different battery voltages for both the cathode and anode simultaneously. The FE analysis of H2 and BAC production in the cathode and anode chambers from five consecutive 1 h controlled current electrolysis (100 mA cm−2) was performed using Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalysts and fresh electrolytes for each cycle. 2.5 Calculation of turnover frequency (TOF) Owing to the bulk nature of the catalysts, we selected an electrochemical method to obtain the TOF values of each sample. Nearly all the surface-active sites are assumed to be accessible by the electrolyte, and then the TOF values could be calculated by the following Eq. (2). (2) T O F = I 2 F n where I, n, and F are current during linear sweep measurement, the number of active site numbers, and the Faraday constant, respectively. Factor 1/2 represents the number of electrons transferred by the TOR process [41–43]. Value n is calculated from the CV data from the RHE in the range from −0.3 to +0.6 V in 1.0 M phosphate buffer (pH = 7.4), with a scan rate of 50 mV s−1. Since it is difficult to attribute the observed peak to a specific redox dual, the surface active site is almost related linearly with the integrated voltammetric charge (cathode and anode) on the CV curve. Assuming a one-electron process for both reduction and oxidation, we can evaluate the upper limit of the active site number according to the following Eq. (3). (3) n = Q C V 2 F 2.6 Calculation of electrochemical active surface areas (ECSA) To estimate the ECSA values of the materials, double-layered capacitance (C dl) is measured using a simple cyclic voltammetry method. The potential is selected beyond the possible Faraday area (0.9–1.0 V vs. RHE) of the material to record the CV at different scan rates of 20–100 mV s−1. The capacitive current density ΔJ/2 is linearly correlated with the scan rate, and the double-layer capacitance (C dl) is calculated from the slope of these straight lines. Using standard specific capacitance values for 1.0 cm−2 surfaces (∼0.04 mF cm−2), the C dl is further converted to ECSA by Eqs. (4) and (5). (4) E C S A = C d l C s (5) C s = 0.04 m F c m - 2 2.7 Product analysis Gas chromatography (GC 7900) equipped with a TCD and FID is used to analyze gas products. Argon (99.99%) is used as the carrier gas. The amount of H2 produced is measured by the water displacement method. Before and after preparing the electrolysis experiment, a liquid aliquot (0.5 mL) is taken, diluted twice with acetonitrile, and analyzed using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) on an Agilent Infinity 1260 II HPLC system equipped with a 220 nm ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) detector. The sample, which has been divided equally, must be passed through a Zorbax SB C-18 chromatography column (4.6 mm × 50 mm, 3.5 μm; Agilent Technologies injection). TL and BAC are quantified using HPLC by generating calibration curves. The mobile phase is 70% methanol + 30% water (containing 0.01% phosphoric acid), with a flow rate of 0.9 mL min−1, a detection wavelength of 225 nm, and a column temperature of 25 °C. TL and BAC can be completely separated within 15 min. Further detection of BAC is determined by 1H NMR and 13C NMR. Before and after electrolysis, the electrolyte was neutralized with HCl, followed by extracting 100 µL of electrolyte, and then 500 µL of CDCl3 was added. The obtained electrolyte was neutralized by HCl before BAC detection. Then, the neutralized electrolyte (100 µL) was mixed with CDCl3 (500 µL) for 1H NMR. The Faraday efficiency is calculated based on the following Eq. (6). (6) F E % = nF × N Q t o t a l c h a r g e p a s s e d × 100 % where n is the number of electrons transferred per product molecule, F is the Faraday constant (96485 C mol−1), N is the number of moles of the product, and Q is the total charge that passed through. BAC conversion rate (%) and product selectivity (%) are calculated via Eqs. (7) and (8). (7) B A C c o n v e r s i o n % = m o l e o f t o l u e n e c o n s u m e d m o l e o f t o l u e n e i n i t i a l × 100 % (8) S e l e c t i v i t y % = m o l e o f b e n z o i c a c i d f o r m e d m o l e o f t o l u e n e c o n s u m e d × 100 % 2.8 In-situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) 0.1222 g of NaOH and 0.2286 g of NaAuCl4·2H2O were dissolved in 3 mL of deionized water and sonicatd for 1 h to obtain solution A. 0.134 g of NH4Cl, 0.9468 g of Na2SO3, and 0.6202 g of Na2S2O3·5H2O were dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water and sonicated for 1 h to obtain solution B. Then, solution A was mixed with solution B, followed by adding 50 mL of deionized water and sonicating thoroughly for 2 h to obtain gold plating solution. Subsequently, the silicon crystals were plated. In Step 1, the silicon crystals were immersed in aqua regia (V (HCl): V (HNO3) = 3:1) for 30 min and then rinsed with deionized water. In Step 2, 50 μm Al2O3 powder was added clockwise on the electrode cloth in the direction of silicon plating for 10 min, and then rinsed with deionized water. In Step 3, the silicon crystals were washed five times alternately with deionized water and acetone for 2, 1, 1, 1, and 2 min. In Step 4, the oxidizing solution was removed (V (H2SO4): V (H2O2) = 3:1) and rinsed with deionized water. Step 5: the silicon coating was soaked in 40% NH4F solution for 4–5 min and rinsed with deionized water. Finally, the gold film was deposited. A 25 mL beaker was filled with 15 mL of gold plating solution, preheated in a water bath at 50–55 °C for 2 min, and then 3.4 mL of 2% HF was added. Subsequently, the prepared silicon crystals were immersed in the above solution for 4–5 min, and finally washed with deionized water to obtain the gold plated layer. 2.9 AEM cell performance Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT and Pt/C powders are dispersed in the mixture of ethanol and Nafion (1:0.05) and sonicated for 1 h to obtain a dispersion with a concentration of 4 mg mL−1. 100 µL dispersion solution was dropped onto the carbon cloth (1 cm × 1 cm), and the catalyst loading is 0.4 mg. Before use, degrease and pretreat in 0.1.0 M HCl solution to remove contaminants from the oxide layer on the instrument surface. Then, the anion exchange membrane (Sustainion X37-50) was sandwiched between the cathode and anode catalyst to build an electrolytic cell (Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT (+) || Pt/C (−)). At room temperature (25 °C), the anode electrolyte (TL + 1.0 M KOH) and the cathode electrolyte (1.0 M KOH solution) are continuously supplied to both sides of the electrolytic cell with a circulating pump at a flow rate of 60 mL min−1. 2.10 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations The study used Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) to perform density functional theory calculations with projector-augmented wave [44,45]. The electron spin-polarization is included in all calculations. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof functional is employed for exchange-correlation effects [46], while DFT + D3 is used for handling weak interactions [47]. The cut-off energy for the plane-wave basis is 450 eV. K-points are 2 × 2 × 1 in the Brillouin zone. 15 Å of layer vacuum is applied at the Z-axis of slab models to avoid the Periodic effect. Energy and maximum stress are converged to 10−5 eV and 0.02 eV Å−1, respectively. The zero-point energy and entropy are corrected. The Gibbs free energy is calculated by Eq. (9). (9) G = E s u r f a c e + a d s o r b a t e - E s u r f a c e + Δ Z P E - T Δ S where G, E, ZPE, T, and S represented the Gibbs free energy, total energy, zero-point energy, temperature, and entropic contributions, respectively. We have added that part in the revised manuscript. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterizations of catalysts The screening of catalysts began with the preparation of a series of metal oxide materials, including CeO2, MnO2, CoO, CuO, and MoO2 (Fig. S1). Among all the catalysts, CeO2 shows the highest FE and BAC yields (Fig. S2). Mn x Ce1− x O2/CNT catalysts are synthesized by a simple solvent-free microwave method [48–51] in a domestic microwave oven for only 1 min (Fig. 1 a). Carbon nanotubes (CNT) [52,53] can transmit microwave energy, have high specific surface area and electrical conductivity, and can be used as supports for dispersing the active components and increasing the number of active sites, as well as facilitating the anchoring of the catalyst and enhancing the stability of the catalyst (Fig. S3). Furthermore, Mn x Ce1− x O2/CNT catalysts with different Ce/Mn ratios are prepared using the same method (Fig. S4), including MnO2/CNT, CeO2/CNT, Mn0.2Ce0.8O2/CNT, Mn0.4Ce0.6O2/CNT, Mn0.5Ce0.5O2/CNT, Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT, and Mn0.8Ce0.2O2/CNT. Five different ratios of Mn x Ce1− x O2/CNT catalysts are determined by ICP-AES (Table S1). Among them, the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst shows the best TOR activity in the TL + 1.0 M KOH. The microstructure of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst is examined by SEM and TEM. As shown in Fig. 1(b, c), the nanoparticles are relatively uniformly loaded on the CNT surface. The structure of the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst is further confirmed by HRTEM images (Fig. 1d). However, due to the introduction of Mn, of which radius is smaller than that of Ce, HRTEM displays a certain degree of lattice contraction, which shows the lattice spacing of 0.302 nm, corresponding to the (111) crystal plane (0.312 nm) of CeO2 [54]. Furthermore, high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) and corresponding energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) element mapping images show that Ce and Mn are uniformly dispersed with an atomic ratio of 4:6, which is in agreement with the ICP-AEM results (Fig. 1e–h and Fig. S5). To further clarify the crystallinity and structure of the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst, XRD analysis is performed [55]. In Fig. 2 (a), the diffraction peaks of pure CeO2 and Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst at 28.5°, 33.0°, 47.4°, 56.4°, and 85.9° are consistent with the cubic fluorite CeO2 (JCPDS No.65-5923). In addition, the XRD pattern of the MnO2 catalyst (Fig. S6) is matched well with hexagonal MnO2 (JCPDS No.89-5171). Meanwhile, the XRD patterns of other prepared Mn x Ce1− x O2/CNT catalysts are tested (Fig. S7). The results show that XRD patterns of Mn x Ce1− x O2/CNT (x ≤ 0.6) display the cubic fluorite CeO2 structure, but the diffraction peaks of MnO2 would appear with the increasing Mn content. Compared to pure CeO2, the diffraction peaks of CeO2 in the Mn x Ce1− x O2/CNT slightly shift to a higher Bragg angle value (Fig. S8), indicating lattice shrinkage. This may be due to the substitution of a larger radius Ce by a smaller radius Mn [56,57]. The surface composition and valence state of the Mn x Ce1− x O2/CNT catalyst are further studied by XPS. The XPS spectra are calibrated to the uncertain carbon (C 1s) line with a binding energy of 284.8 eV. As shown in wide range XPS survey spectra (Fig. S9), the Mn x Ce1− x O2/CNT are essentially composed of the Mn, Ce, and O elements. The Ce/Mn atomic ratio is determined by XPS, which is consistent with ICP (Table S2). To further investigate the chemical environment of different atoms, high-resolution XPS spectra are performed. The high-resolution O 1s spectrum of the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst (Fig. 2b) clearly shows that O 1s has two peaks, one at 529.8 eV, corresponding to lattice oxygen (Olatt), and one at around 531.8 eV, which can be attributed to surface adsorbing oxygen (Oads) [58]. Other catalysts also contain two types of O. In the high-resolution Ce 3d spectrum of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT (Fig. 2c), the peaks at 882.4, 889.0, 898.2, 901.0, 907.5, and 916.7 eV belong to Ce4+ and the peaks at 884.9 and 905.0 eV belong to Ce3+. These peaks suggest that the Ce oxidation state of the catalyst is predominantly +4 and that compared with the CeO2/CNT, the Ce 3d peak of the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT sample shifts to a higher binding energy. The Mn 2p peak (Fig. 2d) consists of 2 major spin orbits. Mn 2p 3/2 at about 641.1 eV indicates Mn3+ and Mn2+ because of the approximate binding energy difference between Mn3+ and Mn2+ [59]. Mn 2p 3/2 at approximately 642.9 eV indicates Mn4+ [60]. Compared with the MnO2/CNT, the Mn 2p peak of the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT sample shifts to a lower binding energy, indicating the existence of electron transfer between Mn and Ce. 3.2 Electrocatalytic performance of catalysts The electrochemical TOR performance of prepared Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalysts is evaluated in a three-electrode system. The electrocatalyst (4.0 mg) is dispersed in 1.0 mL ethanol + Nafion mixed solution. The obtained ink is dropped onto the carbon cloth with the size of 1 × 1 cm2 to get the corresponding electrode. As shown in Fig. S10, the catalyst is successfully loaded onto the carbon cloth. The electrolyte is composed of 1.0 M of TL and 1.0 M KOH. The LSV curves are measured at the scanning rate of 5 mV s−1. Fig. 3 (a) illustrates that the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst exhibits the most optimal performance. The smaller Tafel slope of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT indicates the faster TOR kinetics (Fig. S11). Furthermore, electro-chemical double-layer capacitance (C dl) calculated by CV tests is shown in Fig. S12, which also shows that Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT possesses the optimum active surface area. Similarly, in Fig. S13, Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT displays the largest ECSA than others, facilitating the exposure of more active sites. ECSA normalized polarization curves (Fig. S14) illustrate that the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst exhibits the most optimal TOR activity compared to other catalysts. Fig. S15 shows that the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT electrode has the highest TOF at 100 mV, which is far better than other catalysts. At the same time, Fig. S16 shows that the EIS of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT in Mn x Ce1− x O2/CNT catalyst shows a minimum. Next, the oxidation of TL at the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT electrode is studied using an H-type electrolyzer with an AEM (Fig. S17). The liquid TL and BAC in the anode chamber are measured and quantified by HPLC to evaluate the electrocatalytic products and catalytic efficiency. The corresponding standard lines and chromatogram are shown in Fig. S18. The HPLC of products collected from different catalysts after 1 h catalysis at 2.6 V is shown in Fig. S19(a). As shown in Fig. 3(b, c), the FE varies with the change in Ce/Mn ratio. Among them, the BAC yield, TL conversion, BAC selectivity, and FE of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT are the highest. The results show that Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT is the most suitable catalyst for electrocatalytic oxidation of TL. The HPLC of products collected from Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT after 1 h catalysis at different voltages (from 2.2 to 3.2 V) is performed (Fig. S19b). As shown in Fig. 3(d), the chromatographic peak of TL can be observed before the reaction. After the reaction, the chromatographic peak of TL was weakened, and a clear peak of BAC appeared. The yield conversion, selectivity, FE, and yield of BAC in the anode chamber are shown in Fig. 3(e, f), in which the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT at 2.6 V shows the highest FE (85.9%), conversion rate (55.5%), selectivity (96.3%), and the yield (653.9 mg h−1 cm−2). Fig. S20 shows the outflow time of standard samples of TL and BAC. Further evidence is obtained through 1H NMR (Fig. S21a) and 13C NMR (Fig. S21b) to confirm that the generated product is BAC. The above results show that the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst has excellent TOR performance, which is better than most reported (Table S3). In addition, the electrocatalytic TOR process is safer and more environmentally friendly as it does not use high temperatures, high pressure, and strong oxidants. The tests were conducted under constant temperature conditions (in the water bath). The cell temperature is monitored by means of a temperature probe. Under water bath conditions, the temperature is constant during the reaction, avoiding temperature effects. To make the experiment more rigorous, we analyzed the effect of the weight percentage in Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT on the catalytic TOR activity. During the synthesis of the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst, Ce(NO3)2·6H2O (107.1 mg) and Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (92.9 mg) are mixed by a mortar. The catalyst with a weight percentage of 130% is obtained after the reaction, named Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT-1. Similarly, we prepared Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT-2 with weight percentage of 69% and Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT-3 with weight percentage of 237%. We performed electrochemical TOR using different weight percentages of catalysts. As shown in Fig. S22, the BAC yields are 653.9, 253.9, and 749.1 mg h−1 cm−2. The selectivity is 96.3%, 95.9%, and 96.1%. The FE is 85.9%, 50.9%, and 70.8% respectively. When the weight percentage is low, the TOR performance is poor. When the weight percentage is higher, the change in TOR performance is not significant. Considering the economic benefits, Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT-1 is selected as the best catalyst under different weight percentages. To make the experiment more rigorous, we repeated the experiment by coating the catalyst on the foam Ti. As shown in Fig. S23, under the same experimental conditions, the yield, selectivity, and FE of benzoic acid are not enhanced. Therefore, the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT coated on the surface of carbon cloth is feasible. To further test the stability of the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst, chronoamperometry and chronopotentiometry tests are carried out. The fresh electrolytes are replaced every hour and TL is periodically replenished to the initial concentration. Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT electrode is used as the anode in the fresh electrolyte. As shown in Fig. S24, the controlled chronopotentiometry tests are carried out continuously for 5 h at a rate of 100 mA cm−2 in fresh electrolyte and the chronoamperometry curve is almost the same. Similarly, five consecutive chronoamperometry tests are carried out in the same electrolyte at an electrolyzer voltage of 2.6 V, and the result is consistent with the chronopotentiometry test (Fig. S25). It is worth noting that the significant interruptions between each hour in Fig. S25 are caused by changing the electrolyte. In the subsequent BAC separation process, ethyl acetate is used for extraction followed by distillation under reduced pressure using a rotary evaporator. As shown in Fig. S26, the solubility of BAC in ethyl acetate is very high, and with the boiling point of ethyl acetate at 77.1 °C and that of benzoic acid at 250 °C, BAC can be easily separated in ethyl acetate. The cathode electrocatalyst uses a commercial Pt/C to facilitate HER. The hydrogen produced by the cathode is determined by GC. The standard lines and the corresponding chromatogram of GC are shown in Fig. S27(a, b). The amount of gas produced in the H-type electrolyzer with Mn x Ce1− x O2/CNT as the cathode is measured. By varying the Ce/Mn ratio of the Mn x Ce1− x O2/CNT anode catalysts, the amount of produced H2 at the cathode is also varied (Fig. 3g). Fig. 3(h) compares the total H2 measured in the experiment with the total H2 calculatedfor each electrolysis process. The actual value is greater than the theoretical value due to the occurrence of the side reaction OER. Compared to pure CeO2, the difference between theoretical and actual hydrogen production decreases after Mn is introduced, indicating that Mn regulates the electronic structure of Ce and suppresses OER. As shown in Fig. 3(i), the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT shows the best effect. The SEM images of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT before and after electrolysis show that the morphology of the catalyst had no obvious change after electrolysis (Fig. S28). To reveal the durability of the prepared Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT, the XRD pattern of pristine and post Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT after 50 h service was performed. As shown in Fig. S28(a), the XRD pattern of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT after the TOR process is unchanged, indicating outstanding structural stability. Similarly, the XPS patterns of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT showed no change, further indicating the excellent stability of the catalyst (Fig. S29b–d). In summary, these results confirm the excellent stability of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalysts during long-term electrochemical TOR. 3.3 In-situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis To monitor the dynamic changes in the substrate and product structure during TOR potential dependence, in-situ FTIR is collected within the TL + 1.0 M KOH electrolyte, which ranges from 800 to 1800 cm−1. According to Fig. 4 (a, b), after Mn introduction, the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst exhibits better TOR performance. Meanwhile, the electrocatalytic TOR performance varied with voltage, and the best effect was observed at 2.6 V. In addition, all proportions of Mn x Ce1− x O2/CNT are tested (Fig. 4c), and the results show that Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT is the optimal catalyst for the electrocatalytic TOR. For specific analysis of intermediates and products in TOR, FTIR tests are performed at 2.6 V for 5 min using Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst (Fig. 4d). In the open circuit potential (OCP), a typical aromatic ring vibration of 1602 cm−1 is immediately observed when TL is introduced [61]. The bands at 3063 and 3026 cm−1 can be attributed to the C–H stretching vibration band of aromatic rings [62]. Afterward, the signal of TL is removed to observe the generation of BAC. After introducing TL for 30 s, bands of 2930 and 2875 cm−1 are detected in the C–H stretching zone as symmetric or asymmetric stretching of methylene (–CH2) [63]. In addition, after introducing TL for 1 min, the corresponding band of –CH2 bending vibration is detected at 1411 cm−1 [64–66], which directly reflects the formation of methylene, indicating that benzyl is one of the intermediates for the oxidation of TL to BAC. After introducing TL for 2 min, a band at 1666 cm−1 is detected [67], which can be attributed to the C=O stretching vibration mode of aldehydes. The two bands at 1536 and 1428 cm−1 indicate the formation of carboxylic acid groups (–COOH) [68]. These results indicate that when TL is adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst, the first step is to cleave the C–H bond of TL methyl, detach a hydrogen atom, and form a benzyl radical. Next, benzyl radicals are oxidized to form benzyl alcohol. Reactive oxygen (*OH) oxidizes *C6H5CH2 directly at this point, rather than adsorbing onto the Ce site, and therefore activates the C–H bond to form BAC. Benzophenol is further oxidized to benzaldehyde (C6H5–HC=O), which is then oxidized to BAC. Meanwhile, no characteristic peak of peroxidation product and CO2 is detected, indicating that BAC did not undergo over-oxidation. 3.4 Density functional theory (DFT) calculation analysis Modeling based on XRD results (Fig. S30), among CeO2, MnO2, CoO, CuO, and MoO2 catalysts, CeO2 shows the highest FE and BAC yields. This result agrees well with the DFT calculations (Fig. 5 a). According to the structural characterization, the exposed surfaces of CeO2, MnO2, CoO, CuO, and MoO2 are surrounded by cubic CeO2 (111), hexagonal MnO2 (102), cubic CoO (111), monoclinic CuO (111), and monoclinic MoO2 (011), respectively (Fig. S1). Figs. S31–S35 show the C–H bond activation dehydrogenation of TL on specific surfaces of different metal oxides. Larger free energies indicate less favorable reaction progression. Among all the specific surfaces of various metal oxides, CeO2 (111) had the lowest free energy for C–H bond activation of TL (Fig. 5b). The Ce site promotes the adsorption of TL and intermediate species, and therefore the reactive active sites are all Ce sites in the following reaction steps. To elucidate the improvement of the electrocatalytic TOR performance of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT, DFT calculations are conducted to investigate the structure and energy of key steps in the anodic TOR process (Fig. 5c). The XRD results indicate that Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT has a CeO2 cubic fluorite structure. TEM shows that CeO2/CNT and Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT mainly expose the (111) surface, and the CNT acts as a carrier and does not participate in the reaction process, so CNT is omitted in the modeling. Therefore, modeling first focuses on the CeO2 (111) surface. Meanwhile, the structure and crystal faces of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2 are the same as those of (111). It is worth noting that Mn replaces some Ce sites according to the XRD results. The complete structural models of CeO2 and Mn0.6Ce0.4O2 are shown in Fig. S36. Fig. 5(d, e) shows the TOR process on Mn0.6Ce0.4O2 and CeO2, followed by DFT analysis of changes in the total reaction energy barrier. The corresponding intermediate adsorption model is shown in Figs. S37–S43. The adsorption energy of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2 on TL is lower than that of CeO2 (−0.80 and −0.72 eV). Specifically, TL is first adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst, and one of H in the –CH3 of TL is activated to form *C6H5H2, and then *C6H5H2 combines with * OH to form *C6H5CH2OH. The catalyst adsorbs *C6H5CH2OH and further activates the C–H bond to form *C6H5CHOH, then being oxidized to form *C6H5CHO, and further activates the C–H bond to form *C6H5CO, ultimately leading to the formation of BAC through oxygenation. During the reaction process, the rate-determining step (RDS) is the C–H bond activation process, and Mn0.6Ce0.4O2 reduces the energy barrier of the RDS and accelerates the reaction kinetics. It is worth noting that *C6H5H2 needs to adsorb *OH. However, OER may occur at the anode, when *OH is adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst. Since the free energy of *OH adsorption on the surface of the catalyst is greater than that of *C6H5CH2 and *OH binding, the TOR is more likely to occur than OER, which is consistent with the experimental results observed (Fig. S44). In addition, the adsorption energy of BAC on Mn0.6Ce0.4O2 is lower than that on CeO2 (Fig. S45), so BAC is more readily desorbed on the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2 catalyst and thus not deeply oxidized. This is consistent with the results obtained from the FTIR test spectra where no peroxidation of organic products and CO2 are detected. Through XPS analysis and experimental validation, we found that there is an electron transfer between Ce and Mn, which suggests that Mn can modulate the electronic structure of Ce. Through experimental validation, we found that Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT has the best TOR performance, which further indicates that the introduction of Mn can lead to faster reaction kinetics. Meanwhile, through DFT theoretical calculations, we found that the reaction energy barriers are reduced after the introduction of Mn. Therefore, we conclude that the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst has excellent TOR performance, demonstrating the link between catalyst design and activity enhancement, as well as the specific role of Mn introduction in the activation of C–H bonds. 3.5 AEM cell performance Finally, to investigate the practical application potential of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT, we constructed an AEM electrolyzer using Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT as the anode catalyst for TOR, commercial Pt/C as the cathode catalyst for HER, where the two chambers are separated by an AEM (Fig. 6 a). The anode chamber contains 1.0 M KOH solution containing 1.0 M TL + 1.0 M KOH, while the cathode chamber is filled with water solution containing 1.0 M KOH. To study the TOR performance in AEM cells, the synthesized catalysts have been explored using EIS in AEM cells (Fig. S46). Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT shows the smallest EIS, as seen in the Nyquist plots, indicating its fast electron transfer during the TOR. As shown in Fig. 6(b), the LSV curve of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT (+) || Pt/C (−) shows the performance of exciting TOR and HER, which requires a voltage of 3.0 V to provide 100 mA cm−2. The FE and yield of BAC at different current densities (60–120 mA cm−2) are calculated. In addition, the LSV of CeO2/CNT (+) || Pt/C (−) and MnO2/CNT (+) || Pt/C (−) is shown in Fig. S47. As shown in Fig. 6(c, d), the maximum yield and FE for anodic TOR of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT (+) || Pt/C (−) thermocouple can reach 579.4 mg h−1 cm−2 and 83.6% at 100 mA cm−2, indicating the feasibility of its practical application. Wang’s group studied the electrooxidation of toluene mediated by cobalt (II) at 85 °C for 12 h to produce benzaldehyde, benzoic acid, and benzyl acetate. The catalytic activity is 74%, the selectivity is 91.9%, and the efficiency is 32% [39]. Ma’s group synthesized Co3O4 NN/Ti and Co3O4@MnO2/Ti for toluene oxidation. When the product is benzaldehyde, the catalytic activity is 47.6% and the selectivity is 90%. When the product is benzyl alcohol, the catalytic activity is 32.1% and the selectivity is 90.1%. When the product is benzyl acetate, the catalytic activity is 58.5% and the selectivity is 92%. The FE is above 80% [40]. We reported that the catalytic activity is 55.5%, the selectivity is 96.3%, and the FE is 85.9% for the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst in the TOR reaction. In addition, the AEM cell has a catalytic activity of 49.3%, a selectivity of 96.1%, and an efficiency of 83.5%, which outperforms similar reactions that have been reported. In addition, such an innovative hybrid electrosynthesis system exhibits superior stability, as manifested by the steady chronoamperometry curve at 3.0 V (100 mA cm−2) and the steady FE for 50 h (Fig. 6e). 4 Conclusions In summary, we found that CeO2 has the best activation effect on C–H bonds by screening a series of metal oxides. The Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst is successfully synthesized for the anodic electrocatalytic TL oxidation reaction with high selectivity to BAC. The optimized Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst could provide a current density of 100 mA cm−2 at 2.6 V. The yield and FE of BAC reached 653.9 mg h−1 cm−2 and 85.9%, while the selectivity is 96.3% and the conversion is 55.5%. The above results show that the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst has excellent TOR performance, which is not only safe and environmentally friendly but also better than most reported catalysts (Table S3). We constructed an AEM electrolyzer using Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT as the anode catalyst for TOR and commercial Pt/C as the cathode catalyst for HER. The yield of BAC is 579.4 mg h−1 cm−2 with 83.6% FE at a voltage of 3.0 V and a current density of 100 mA cm−2. Experimental results and DFT calculations indicate that on the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst, Ce sites promote TL adsorption and polyvalent Mn modulates the electronic structure of Ce sites reducing the rate-determining step energy barrier. This results in increasing *C6H5CH2 coverage and effectively accelerating TOR kinetics. In addition, the Mn–O bond strength is highly stable, so the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT catalyst does not show any significant current density decay after 50 h of catalysis. This work achieved high selectivity TOR at industrial-relevant current densities of 100 mA cm−2 at the low voltage for the first time. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic toluene (TL) oxidation to produce benzoic acid (BAC) process is largely hindered due to sluggish kinetics associated with the transformation of the rate-determining step, because of weak TL adsorption and high rate-determining step energy barrier for difficult to dehydrogenate. Herein, we report Mn x Ce1- x O2/CNT catalyst for accelerated reaction kinetics. Theoretical and experimental studies indicate that Ce sites promote TL adsorption and polyvalent Mn modulates the electronic structure of Ce sites reducing the rate-determining step energy barrier. This results in increasing *C6H5CH2 coverage and effectively accelerating TL oxidation reaction (TOR) kinetics. Excitingly, the Faraday efficiency (FE) and BAC yield of optimized Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT at 2.6 V vs. RHE could reach 85.9% and 653.9 mg h−1 cm−2, respectively. In addition, the Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT displays a high selectivity of 96.3% for BAC. Combining the TL oxidation reaction with hydrogen evolution reaction, the anion exchange membrane electrolyzer of Mn0.6Ce0.4O2/CNT (+) ||Pt/C (−) can reach 100 mA cm−2 at the voltage of 3.0 V, in which the BAC yield is 579.4 mg h−1 cm−2 and the FE is 83.6%. This work achieved high selectivity of TOR at industrial-relevant current densities of 100 mA cm−2 at the low voltage for the first time.
